column3: A categorical label defining a degree of alveolar resorption.

column4: Lukacs, J. R. (1989). Dental pathology: Methods for reconstructing dietary patterns. In Iscan, M. Y. & Kennedy, K. A. R. (Eds.), Reconstruction of life from the skeleton. New York: Liss, p.271.

column3: Slight alveolar resorption, less than one half of the tooth root is exposed.
column4: Lukacs, J. R. (1989). Dental pathology: Methods for reconstructing dietary patterns. In Iscan, M. Y. & Kennedy, K. A. R. (Eds.), Reconstruction of life from the skeleton. New York: Liss, p.271.

column3: Moderate alveolar resorption: More than one half of the tooth root is exposed.
column4: Lukacs, J. R. (1989). Dental pathology: Methods for reconstructing dietary patterns. In Iscan, M. Y. & Kennedy, K. A. R. (Eds.), Reconstruction of life from the skeleton. New York: Liss, p.271.

column3: Severe alveolar resorption: Evulsion of the tooth while remnants of the alveolus are still discernible.
column4: Lukacs, J. R. (1989). Dental pathology: Methods for reconstructing dietary patterns. In Iscan, M. Y. & Kennedy, K. A. R. (Eds.), Reconstruction of life from the skeleton. New York: Liss, p.271.

column3: Complete alveolar resorption: Evulsion of the tooth and complete obliteration of the alveolus.
column4: Lukacs, J. R. (1989). Dental pathology: Methods for reconstructing dietary patterns. In Iscan, M. Y. & Kennedy, K. A. R. (Eds.), Reconstruction of life from the skeleton. New York: Liss, p.271.
column5: The original definition is “Complete – tooth evulsed, alveoli completely obliterated”. Here, the definition is formulated pertaining to one alveolus in order to keep it in line with the definition of the other categories in the source that are all formulated for individual tooth roots, teeth and alveoli.
